titleStmt.title: A dog's elegy, or, Rvpert's tears, for the late defeat given him at Marstonmoore, neer York, by the three renowned generalls; Alexander Earl of Leven, general of the Scottish forces, Fardinando, Lord Fairefax, and the Earle of Manchester generalls of the English Forces in the North. Where his beloved dog, named Boy, was killed by a valiant souldier, who had skill in necromancy. Likewise the strange breed of this shagg'd cavalier, whelp'd of a malignant water-witch; with all his tricks, and feats. Sad Cavaliers, Rupert invites you all that does survive, to his dogs funerall. Close-mourners are the witch, Pope, & devill, that much lament ye'r late befallen evill.

titleStmt.title: A dog's elegy, or, Rvpert's tears, for the late defeat given him at Marstonmoore, neer York, by the three renowned generalls; Alexander Earl of Leven, general of the Scottish forces, Fardinando, Lord Fairefax, and the Earle of Manchester generalls of the English Forces in the North. Where his beloved dog, named Boy, was killed by a valiant souldier, who had skill in necromancy. Likewise the strange breed of this shagg'd cavalier, whelp'd of a malignant water-witch; with all his tricks, and feats. Sad Cavaliers, Rupert invites you all that does survive, to his dogs funerall. Close-mourners are the witch, Pope, & devill, that much lament ye'r late befallen evill.
titleStmt.author: Taylor, John, 1580-1653.

notesStmt.note: Perhaps by John Taylor, the water poet. cf. NUC pre-1956.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DOGS ELEGY, OR RVPERTS TEARS, For the late Defeat given him at Mar≈øtonmoore, neer York, by the Three Renowned Generalls; Alexander Earl of Leven, Generall of the Scotti≈øh Forces, Fardinando Lord Fairefax, and the Earle of Manche≈øter Generalls of the Engli≈øh Forces in the North.
Where his beloved Dog, named BOY, was killed by a Valliant Souldier, who had skill in Necromancy.
Likewi≈øe the ≈øtrange breed of this Shagg'd Cavalier, whelp'd of a Malignant Water-witch; With all his Tricks, and Feats.

q.l: Sad Cavaliers, Rupert invites you all
That doe ≈øurvive, to his Dogs Funerall.
Clo≈øe-mourners are the Witch, Pope, & devill,
That much lament yo'r late befallen evill.

div.p: Printed at London, for G. B. July 27. 1644.

div.head: A Dogg's Elegie, OR R∆≤PERTS Tears.

lg.l: LAment poor Caevaliers, cry, howl and yelp
For the great lo≈ø≈øe of your Malignant Whelp,
Hee's dead! Hee's dead? No more alas can he
Protect you Dammes, or get Victorie.
How ≈øad that Son of Blood did look to hear
One tell the death of this ≈øhagg'd Cavalier, P. Ruperts ≈øorrow.
Hee rav'd, he tore his Perriwigg, and ≈øwore,
Again≈øt the Round-heads that hee'd ne're fight more:
Clo≈øe couch'd, as in a field of Beanes he lay,His policie.
Cur≈øing and banning all that live-long day;
Thou≈øands of Devills Ramme me into Hell,
Or may I live and die an Infidell,
The Day's quite lo≈øt, wee are all confounded,
And made a prey to ev'ry paltry Roundhead;
Ju≈øt Heav'n had ≈øo Decreed, as it fell out,
The Cavaliers receiv'd a finall Rout.
Manche≈øter, Le≈ølie, Fairefax weares the Bay. His Army Routed.
And Crumwell crown'd chief Victor of the Day;
VVhile thou≈øands weltring in their blood, did lie
VVeary of life, and yet afraid to die.
But for to tell of this Bl ‚Ä¢ ck Water-witch, His Dogs Progeny.
That puppy'd was of a Malignant Bitch,
Or Hagge, ≈øo cunning in her Art, that ≈øhee
VValk'd under earth „Äà‚óä„Äâ in the aire „Äà‚óä„Äâ flie,The property of Witches.
Sell windes ≈øhe could, command the Ebb or Tide,
Rai≈øe Foggs, give Spells or on the Clowds could ride,
For Magick, Sorcery, Charme or Evill,

She well, might
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to th' Devill.
This Witch one night, late, picking banefull Drugs,
Her Spirit.Meeting grim Brenno, us'd to ≈øuck her duggs,
In ≈øhape of a young ≈øtripling Dammy Blade,
For Whoredome, Murder, and for Rapine made,
For all the world, ≈øome ≈øay, ju≈øt ≈øuch another
That u≈øed to call Prince Maurice brother:
Thus ≈øhee Accoa≈øted him, What Forme is this
Thou ha≈øt a≈ø≈øum'd Brenno? By the Aby≈ø≈øe,
My blood rebells more powerfull then my Charmes,
Till I doe lodge thee in my twined armes.
The dog begotten.No ≈øooner had ≈øhee ≈øpake, but a black clowde
VVith duskie curtains did them both en≈øhrowde,
VVhere was begotten this Malignant Curr,
VVho in this Iland hath made all this ≈øtirre.
Full thrice three yeears within her cur≈øed wombe,
He did remaine, ere he to light did come:
The long'd for houre is come, mo≈øt ≈øtrange to tell,
The Furies ≈øtraight about their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe fell;
Megera midwife was to this ≈øtrange Fiend,
For who≈øe delivery all the Haggs attend:
Thunder and Earth quakes ≈øuch a noi≈øe did make,
As if Heavens Axletree in ≈øunder brake,
And either Poles, their heads together pa≈øh'd,
As all againe they had to Chaos da≈øh'd:
Then was a noi≈øe, as if the Garden Beares,
And all the Doggs together by the Eares,
And tho≈øe in Bedlam had inlarged been,
And to behold the bayting had come in.
Signs of prodigious births.About by noon flew the affrighted Owls,
And Dogs in corners ≈øet them down to howle,
Bitches and Wolves the≈øe fatall ≈øignes among,
Brought forth mo≈øt mon≈øtrous, and prodigious young:
And from his height, the earth-refre≈øhing Sun,
Before his houre his golden beams doth run
Farre under us, in doubt his glorious Eye
Should be polluted with this Progedy.
A trembling fear ≈øtraight on the people grew,
But for what cau≈øe there was not one that knew,
Th' De≈øtinies, Furyes, Fates, and all hells Crew
Came trembling in, and would this Mon≈øter view,
And long it was not ere there came to light.
The mo≈øt abhorred, and mo≈øt fearfull ≈øight
That ever eye beheld, a birth ≈øo ≈øtrange,
That at the view it made their looks to change:
VVomen ≈øtand off (quoth one) and come not neer it,The dogges birth.
The Devill, if he ≈øaw it, ≈øure would fear it,
For by it's ≈øhape, for ought that I can gather,
The Childe is able to affright the Father:
'Twas like a Dog, yet there was none did know
VVhether it Devill was, or Dog, or no.
Scarce twice two yeers pa≈øt o're,His cunning. but quickly hee
Excell'd his Mother in her VVitcherie,
And in his black and gloomy Arts ≈øo skill'd,
That he even Hell in his ≈øubjection held;
Hee could command the Spirits up from below,
And binde them ≈øtrongly, till they let him know
All the dread ≈øecrets that belong them to,
And what tho≈øe did, with whom they had to doe.
This VVizard in his knowledge mo≈øt profound,His depth of skill‚ñ™
Sate on a day the depths of things to ≈øound,
For that the VVorld was brought to ≈øuch a pa≈ø≈øe,
That it well nere in a confu≈øion was,
For things ≈øet right, ran quickly out of frame,
And tho≈øe awrie, to rare perfection came,
And matters in ≈øuch ≈øort about were brought,
That States were puzzl'd almo≈øt beyond thought,
VVhich made him thinke as he might very well,
There were more Devills then he knew in hell.
Now for to Act his part he doth beginne,
And tempt's the VVorld to all abhorred ≈øinne:
To Rome he fir≈øt re≈øolves his cour≈øe to ≈øteere,His fir≈øt trick.
And quickly leaps into the Prelates Chaire,
Ju≈øt 'bout the time ≈øome think when as Pope Jone
VVas head o'the Church, and troubled with the ≈øtone,
He cur'd her Holine≈ø≈øe, brought her abed,
And ≈øhew'd the Romi≈øh Church her Maiden head:
But finding Rome already prone to Vice,
To Pride, Vain-glory, Lu≈øt and Avarice,
To Murder, Rape, Idolatry and more
Then he (though Devill) ever knew before,
For Spaine hee comes, ju≈øt about Eighty Eight,
And there a Fleet he Rigg'd for England ≈øtreight,
The great Armado.There did hee play his Water-prize with Dr ‚Ä¢ ke,
Who with Earth's thunder, made proud Neptune quake;
He taught this Dog to Duck, to ≈øwim, and dive,
Till ≈øcarce a Spaniard he had left alive;
But being vex'd, mi≈ø≈øing his aime at Sea,
He vow'd on Land revenged he would be,
Queen Elizabeth many times miraculou≈øly delivered.But Heav'n which ever did Protect that Queene,
Debarr'd his malice, and repell'd his ≈øpleene;
Till Jove fetching her hence, gave her a Crowne,
More bright, more glorious, and of more renowne,
Who Reignes till Time hath date, or Fame hath breath,
Queen of true Engli≈øh hearts in life and death.
Aurora's gone: Bright Sol is in his Throne,
Then dry your eyes, and cea≈øe for her to mourne:
This Dogge now ca≈øts about, tries all his skill,
To poy≈øon, ≈øtab, or ≈øome new way to kill
Never yet heard of; The Ma≈øter-piece of hell
The Popi≈øh Powder-plot.Is now contriv'd that wants a Paralell,
The Powder-Plot, that would in one half houre,
King, Prince, Peers, Commons, at one blow devower,
But then he failed too, the Eye of Heav'n
De≈øcri'd the Plot, and Ju≈øtice with an even
Impartiall hand, by the Decree of Jove,
Set free our Kingdom, and did them remove,
Gave them their ju≈øt reward, ≈øent them to Hell,
'Mong≈øt better Devills then them≈øelves and well.
Our Dog is ma≈øterle≈ø≈øe; Could he but frame
Him≈øelf to ≈øerve the Fav'rite Buckingham,
The Dog turns Courtier.This cunning, ≈ølie, in≈øinuating Elfe,
By him would work ≈øtrange wonders for him≈øelf,
Then doth he Plot, contrive and ca≈øt about ‚ñ™
And Hell it ≈øelf doth ≈øearch, for to finde out,
If any way were left, he vow'd to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Once more to bring this land to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .
Duke of Lenox. Now dies that Noble Scot, who „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ s tell,
'Twas thy Ambition made his carcas≈øe ≈øwell.
Prince Henry. Next, Prince Henry‚ÄîBut here my Mu≈øe ≈øtrikes ≈øaile,
A damp glide through „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
I know not, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øome powerfull Spell
Hath charm'd my head into a watery VVell:

l.hi: "Eyes weep out tears, tears weep out eyes in kindne≈ø≈øe,
"Since he is dead, how be≈øt of all is blindne≈ø≈øe.

lg.l: A Match with Spaine mu≈øt now be practi≈øed,
VVhich ≈øoon will ≈øtrike the nayle up to the head:
Oh, now it works, which makes his Holine≈ø≈øe, The Popes letter.
Salute his hopefull Sonne with an Expre≈ø≈øe,
An≈øwer'd with ≈øo much Candor to the Chaire,
As if Him≈øelf of it did ≈øtand in feare.
The Match broak off with Spaine, our Noble BOY
Is yet to ≈øeek, and mu≈øt finde out a way
By Poy≈øon ≈øtill, how that (O mon≈øtrous!) Hee
More home may ≈øtrike at Sacred Maje≈øtie,
Great Brittains KING, and Europs chiefe≈øt glory,K. James his death.
Scarce parallel'd in any Engli≈øh Story,
Mu≈øt with White Powder given him in his drinke,
Cry out on him that made his Carca≈ø≈øe ≈øinke.

O for a Bi≈øhop now, Come Little Land,
Canterbury u≈øhers in popery.
And u≈øher in the Babyloni≈øh Baud,
This made him Metropolitan, when hee
Did move the Duke to goe toth' Ile of Ree, The Ile of Rue voyage.
Poore Rochell Ru'd it, where by more then Chance,
England was made the ≈øcorne of conquer'd France:
But heaven by Felton's hand had ≈øo decreed,
He that ≈øhed all this blood, him≈øelf ≈øhould bleed.
Now Bi≈øhops, Coaps, Caps, Surplices and Cro≈ø≈øes,
Mu≈øt needs Religion-o're the≈øe fattall Lo≈ø≈øes:
GODS Day mu≈øt be Profan'd with Sports profane,The Declaration for Sports on the Sabbath-day.
Laud, White, and Wren, like Tyrant-Kings mu≈øt Reign:
Monopolies impos'd, and none goe free,
But tho≈øe that lou'd the Ma≈ø≈øe, and Popery.
Now Tips of Ears, and burning fiery ≈øcarres,Mr. Burton, Mr. Prynne, and Dr. Ba≈øtwick.
VVere all ≈øad Symptoms of in≈øuing VVarres!
That Ma≈ø≈øe-Book unto Scotland now mu≈øt trace, Scotlands piety.
Or el≈øe a Bloody Sword ≈øupplies the place.
Now doth that ≈øur-Reverend Piece of Lu≈øt, Queen mother.
That Madam Pole cat, that was never ju≈øt,
Contrive and Plot, and wrack her whoary ≈øcull,
Urging her Daughter to make mi≈øchief full.
Now Strafford's on the di≈ømall Stage: 'tis hee
Mu≈øt Act chief part in this red Tragedie:
Traytors, and papi≈øts, Whe ‚Ä¢ ps of the ≈øame litter.Now Harry Jemin, Bri≈øtoll, Digby, Cott.‚Äî
Mu≈øt all to work, and ≈øee what they can Plot:
Now Bleeding Ireland hath by Commi≈ø≈øion,
Brought th' Prot'≈øtants to a ≈øad condition:
Two hundred thou≈øand of them lately ≈ølaine,
The Prote≈øtant Religion to maintaine.
'Tis time the King now leave his Parliament,
Let Digby weare his Crown, and give con≈øent
To rai≈øe an Army Traytors to protect,
And his Great Coun≈øell utterly reject.
The Dogs Ma≈øter.Now Prince of Robbers, Duke of Plunderland,
This Dogs great Ma≈øter, hath receiv'd command
To kill, burne, ≈øteale, Ravi≈øh, nay, any thing,
And in the end to make him≈øelf a King.
Newca≈øtle next, Capell the Cow ≈øtealer,
The≈øe and Iri≈øh Rebells, his Maie≈øties be≈øt Subjects. And Ha≈øtings alias Rob-Carrier,
Hopton, Hurry, Lunsford, that all doe Fight
For the true Go≈øpel, and the Subjects Right.
On A≈øhton, Legge, and ≈øuch as the≈øe doe ≈øtand
The Priviledge of Parliament and Land!
And the Known Laws, that ≈øhould good men protect,
Upheld by Rebells, that good men reiect,
O durum hoc! ‚ÄîMine eyes bur≈øt out to thinke
How blinde he is, that can at the≈øe things winke.
To tell you all the pranks this Dogge hath wrought,
That lov'd his Ma≈øter, and him Bullets brought,
VVould but make laughter, in the≈øe times of woe,
Or how this Curr came by his fatall blow,
Look on the Title page, and there behold,
The Emblem will all this to you unfold.

lg.head: MORRALL.
lg.l: The VVorld's the VVitch, the Dogge, is the Devill,
And men th' Actors, that have wrought this evill.

lg.head: EPILOGUE.

l.hi: He that can't get a peny me to buy,

lg.l: May want a Pound, and a Malignant die.
